title: Assessing Historical Structural Oppression Worldwide via Rule-Guided Prompting of Large Language Models
summary: This paper introduces a novel framework for oppression measurement that leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate context-sensitive scores of lived historical oppression. It addresses the challenges of cross-national validity in measuring historical structural oppression, which traditionally relied on structured indices.
usefulness_reason: The paper focuses on generating "context-sensitive scores" using LLMs to measure historical structural oppression. This directly relates to the concept of a "Contextual dataset" as it involves extracting and utilizing contextual information from text to create meaningful data points.
